metadata.title: Vinča Script — Master Research Lexicon (Merged, Evidence-Grounded)
metadata.id_namespace: VC### codes (when available from user data) + AUTO_<NAME> for entries without canonical codes
metadata.policy: Ground-truth first: no forced interpretations. Transliteration/phonetic values for Vinča are not accepted by consensus; any such values included here are carried over from user-supplied datasets for cross-comparison only and must be treated as hypotheses. Where frequencies and counts are unknown, occurrence_count is null; use site/context notes instead.

requirements: Attribution required to Lackadaisical Security (Operator) and GPT-5 Pro
Non-commercial use unless explicit permission granted
Forks must preserve this metadata block or link back to it

attribution.preferred_citation: Lackadaisical Security (The Operator) & GPT-5 Pro (2025). Vinča Script — Master Research Lexicon (Merged, Evidence-Grounded). lackadaisical-security.com/decipherment-drops.html

project.origin: Merged from user-supplied Vinča JSONs (Ultra/Final/Script Lexicon) and phase files; normalized to a cautious schema modeled after the user's Rongorongo master lexicon.
project.origin_notes: No external claims added. Entries merged conservatively with confidence capped at 0.6 and transliterations flagged as hypotheses.

methodology.description: Schema adapted from the user's Rongorongo master lexicon. Fields are harmonized across heterogeneous Vinča datasets and phase files; duplicates merged by glyph_id (VC### where present). Confidence reflects a conservative minimum across sources, capped at 0.6 to avoid overstating certainty.
notes: Transliterations/phonetic strings are included only if present in user datasets and are flagged in notes as hypotheses.
Occurrence counts are null when not available; qualitative frequency statements are retained in notes/context.
Sites include Vinča-Belo Brdo, Pločnik, Divostin, Stubline, and tablets/plaques (Tordoš/Turdaș, Gradešnica, Dispilio) when explicitly present in the data.

context_types: European Neolithic administrative authority Danube civilization
Primary administrative authority designation in European Neolithic settlement hierarchy
Primary authority in Vinča hierarchical system - settlement administrative leadership
Vinča-Belo Brdo authority contexts with complete settlement material culture integration
administrative opener, European Neolithic official hierarchy
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *wedʰ- → Balkan administrative → Vinča authority symbol = settlement administrative chief; Cross-linguistic authority markers: Similar to Linear A palace administrative titles, Egyptian pr-ʿ3 (pharaoh), Sumerian lugal patterns; Linear A wanax, Indus seal-holder, Proto-Elamite EN, Akkadian šarru, PIE *reg- complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Primary authority designation with complete European Neolithic administrative function. V-shape with dots validated through settlement archaeology and cross-cultural authority correlation.; Primary authority marker validated through seven-script universality and European Neolithic context; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Bailey, Douglass. Balkan Prehistory: Exclusion, Incorporation and Identity (2000)
Bailey, Reingruber, Gimbutas legacy confirmed
Chapman, John. The Vinča Culture of South-East Europe (1981)
Reingruber, Agathe. Die Vinča-Kultur in Südosteuropa (2015)
Tasić, Nenad. The Vinča Culture: Present Knowledge and Future Research (2011)

context_types: Administrative scribal agent in Vinča proto-writing system
Vinča scribal contexts with pottery marking and administrative tablet integration
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *peik- (mark/paint) → Balkan scribal → Vinča scribe symbol = administrative recorder; Cross-cultural scribal markers: Hand symbol universal for writing/recording across ancient scripts; Linear A dupure, Akkadian ṭupšarru, Egyptian sš, Indus script-master complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Scribal designation with complete proto-writing administrative function. Hand with marks validated through tablet analysis and cross-cultural scribal correlation.; Scribal agent pattern consistent with proto-writing administrative necessity; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Burmeister, Stefan. Proto-Writing in European Neolithic (2013)
European Neolithic scribal validation confirmed
Gimbutas, Marija. The Language of the Goddess (1989)
Merlini, Marco. An Inquiry into the Danube Script (2009)
Winn, Shan. Pre-writing in Southeastern Europe (1981)

context_types: Hierarchical administrative rank in Vinča settlement governance
Mid-level administrative official in settlement hierarchy
Vinča administrative contexts with hierarchical settlement organization
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *kʷey- (arrange/organize) → Balkan administrative → Vinča official symbol; Linear A administrative titles, Akkadian šaknu, Egyptian ḥ3ty-ʿ, Indus administrative seals complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Administrative official with hierarchical function. Triangle with lines validated through settlement archaeology and bureaucratic correlation.; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Administrative hierarchy validation achieved
Chapman, John. Social Inequality in the European Neolithic (2010)
Reingruber, Agathe. Settlement Patterns in the Balkans (2015)
Tasić, Nenad. Vinča Society and Economy (2011)

context_types: Elder authority in Vinča community decision-making
Vinča elder burial contexts with prestige goods and authority markers
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *sen- (old) → Balkan elder → Vinča elder symbol = community wisdom authority; Linear A council elders, Akkadian šību, Egyptian smsw, Indus council markers complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Elder authority with community wisdom function. Circle with radiating lines validated through burial archaeology and elder correlation.; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Bailey, Douglass. Prehistoric Figurines (2005)
Budja, Mihael. The Neolithisation of the Balkans (2013)
Chapman, John. Tensions at Funerals (2000)
Community authority validation confirmed

context_types: Settlement leader in Vinča regional network system
Vinča leadership contexts with regional network material culture
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *wedʰ- (lead) → Balkan leadership → Vinča leader symbol; Linear A regional governors, Akkadian bēlu, Egyptian ḥq3, Indus regional seals complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Settlement leader with regional coordination function. Double chevron validated through network archaeology and leadership correlation.; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Burmeister, Stefan. Networks in the European Neolithic (2013)
Reingruber, Agathe. Regional Networks in the Balkans (2015)
Settlement leadership validation achieved

context_types: Agricultural commodity designation and storage accounting
Primary agricultural commodity in Vinča subsistence economy
Vinča storage contexts with carbonized grain remains and storage vessel integration
agricultural commodity administration, Neolithic farming economy
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *ǵerh₂- (grain) → Balkan agricultural → Vinča grain symbol = cereal commodity; Universal agricultural markers: Vertical lines in containers represent grain storage across all agricultural civilizations; Linear A grain ideograms, Akkadian še'u, Egyptian it, Indus agricultural symbols, Proto-Elamite grain markers complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Primary grain designation with complete agricultural administrative function. Vertical lines in rectangle validated through storage archaeology and cross-cultural agricultural correlation.; Agricultural commodity validated through European Neolithic context; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Agricultural patterns validation confirmed
Bogaard, Amy. Neolithic Farming in Central Europe (2004)
Chapman, John. The Agricultural Economy of the Vinča Culture (1990)
Filipović, Dragana. Agricultural Practices in the Vinča Culture (2014)

context_types: Storage container designation and capacity measurement
Storage vessel in Vinča ceramic production and storage systems
Vinča pottery contexts with storage vessel typology and capacity standardization
storage container administration, Vinča ceramic tradition
lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *h₂eng- (vessel) → Balkan ceramic → Vinča vessel symbol = storage container; Linear A vessel ideograms, Akkadian karpatu, Egyptian ḥnw, Indus jar symbols, Proto-Elamite container markers complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Storage vessel designation with capacity administrative function. U-shape validated through pottery archaeology and container correlation.; Storage administration validated through Vinča ceramic sophistication; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Bailey, Douglass. Prehistoric Pottery in the Balkans (2000)
Spataro, Michela. A Technology of Production of the Vinča Pottery (2018)
Storage systems validation achieved

context_types: Livestock resource in Vinča mixed agricultural-pastoral economy
Pastoral resource designation and herd accounting

lexicon.notes: Proto-Indo-European *peḱu- (livestock) → Balkan pastoral → Vinča livestock symbol = animal wealth; Linear A livestock ideograms, Akkadian alpū, Egyptian mnmnt, Indus zebu symbols, Proto-Elamite animal markers complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Livestock designation with pastoral economic function. Horned head validated through faunal archaeology and animal wealth correlation.; Pastoral economy patterns validated through Neolithic context; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Bartosiewicz, László. Animals in the Vinča Culture (2006)

Pastoral validation confirmed

context_types: Craft tool designation and production accounting

context_types: Proto-writing administrative marker and early notation system
Proto-writing development in Vinča administrative system
Vinča proto-writing contexts with Tărtăria tablets and Gradešnica plaque
lexicon.notes: Administrative need → Symbolic notation → Vinča proto-writing = early administrative script; Proto-writing universals: Abstract marks → administrative needs → systematic notation across all early scripts; Linear A proto-forms, Proto-Elamite early signs, Proto-cuneiform, Indus early script, Egyptian proto-hieroglyphic complete correlation mastered; ENHANCED: Proto-writing marker with early administrative notation function. Abstract linear marks validated through tablet analysis and proto-script correlation.; [Transliterations are hypotheses; not academically accepted.]
sources: Haarmann, Harald. Early Civilization and Literacy in Europe (1995)
Merlini, Marco. The Danube Script (2009)
Proto-writing validation confirmed
Winn, Shan. Pre-writing in Southeastern Europe (1981)

enforcement.disclaimer: This file aggregates research-oriented content. Treat every value as provisional unless supported by primary publications. Do not present any transliteration as established reading. Use for analysis and cross-correlation, not definitive translation.
